column1: Inflammation of the Nose due to an Allergy
column2: dpbrick, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I don't know about all the side effects reported here.  Perhaps some people are more sensitive than others, or perhaps some people aren't following the recommended dosage.  I'm not questioning the reports; just stating my own experience. I have had nothing but great results with this drug, using it conjunction with fexofenadine.  Generally I use one spray in each nostril, twice each day, once in the am, and once in the pm.  I start using it only when fexofenadine, used alone, can no longer control my seasonal allergy symptoms.  I discontinue use, generally about the time of our first frost.I'm been very happy with it over about the last 4 yrs.  I don't like the idea of taking any medication every day, but when you can't talk without dripping nasal discharge, this is an alternative that works.

column2: KitKat, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)

Wish I had learned more about it, I cannot say that enough.  This was I believe the biggest health mistake I have ever made.  Wish I could take that one day back. Now, just trying to recover.

column1: Chronic Inflammation of the Nose Not due to Allergies
column2: wannabbetter, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I have Asthma/COPD/Bronchitis/Emphyzma. I have been using generic Flonase for about 4 days. My vision is blurry,headaches,nasusa,heavyness in my chest, achy and tight in my chest and really hard breathing. It does work to open up my nose but that doesn't make any difference if I smother to death in the process. Be aware of this product. I haven't been out of the house since I started this medication. Am also weak and have pain in my knees and swelling in feet/ankles, and in my face and throat. Will not take this again.

column1: Chronic Inflammation of the Nose Not due to Allergies
column2: Kris, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I have been on and off the generic for a little over a year. It started for seasonal allergies, but now I am on it full time. I also take generic for albuterol, advair, an epinephrine inhaler, zyrtec-d for am, zyrtec for pm, ibuprophen, prednisone, and do simply saline irrigations. Last fall the zyrtec, flonase, and occasional albuterol were enough but now I can't breath at all with out this whole regimen. I am not blaming the increased severity of asthma on the flonase, my symptoms get drastically worse each year anyway and the doc suspects a possible underlying auto-immune disorder. The steroids have actually eased chronic joint pain that I always have. I haven't so far had the reactions described by others(some of the minor ones, at first, but they subsided after the first few months), many of what people are describing as reactions describe how I feel everyday without this medication, but if anything, those particular symptoms have improved or not changed. I'm an artist with a predisposition to glaucoma and can't afford to suffer the negative visual side-effects, but still take this medication combined with more frequent visits to the eye doc because of the benefits of being able to breathe. Please remember that this is a steroid (I hate that I'm always on 3 or 4 but can't breathe otherwise)and if you can get by without taking steroids, that's usually better for most people. I wouldn't recommend using this drug if an oral antihistamine works for you, but would recommend it to people who aren't helped enough without steroids.

column1: Other
column2: TF2012, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: My husband and I were put on this for chronic sinus pain (clogged sinuses). He was ok after one use! I used it for the first time and my heart rate shot up to 110bpm. I felt like I was having a panic attack. Then, an hour later, my sinuses drained with such ferocity that I had a coughing fit that lasted an hour. I will never take it again. Meanwhile, today, the day after, my sinuses are 10x more painful, also my ears, eustacian tubes and throat are all very sore- worse than they ever were without the drug. I'm going to invest in a neti pot and try to go the natural route.

column1: Chronic Inflammation of the Nose Not due to Allergies
column2: p_patton, 65-74 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Flonase was prescribed by my ENT for allergies and it was working. I used it at night before bedtime and it helped with breathing. Also slowed mucus from post nasal drip.I thought I knew about any possible side effects but there is one side effect that is rare...glaucoma. I awoke with the most terrible pain ever and experienced vomiting and trouble opening my eye. The pupil looked as if it had been dialated. Went to my Opthomologist. He diagnosed Angle Closure Glaucoma attack. My eye pressure was over three times the normal range. Doctor and staff worked for over two hours trying to get the pressure down and he finally performed a lazer procedure. Very dangerous and scary situation. I had just had my eye exam a few months prior and no sign of cataracts or glaucoma. Even though this is an unusual and rare side effect it should be made more known to people using the Flonase product. I could have and may still suffer some vision loss.

column2: www.catchonfirenow.com, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have never had a bad reaction to a drug before. When I first developed the symptoms, I thought it was just my body adjusting. I had been divinely healed of fibromyalgia after 5 and 1/2 years. I thought maybe I was exercising too hard and my body was just reacting. Then I thought this is about the time I started using Flonase. I used it for about 4 weeks. I developed three conditions:  asthma-like symptoms-difficulty breathing/like my throat was partially closed/wheezing and coughing & extreme anxiety & occular migraine-type headaches. I am weaning myself off it. I cut down this morning to about 1/2 spray in each nostril, and the symptoms went about about 90 per cent. I guess I found the culprit. I am going to use a over-the-counter nasal saline spray to keep my nose and sinuses lubricated.

column9: I actually started with Nasacort for Spring and Fall seasonal allergies ( and a bit of travel), then switched to Flonase when that became available (less $$$). I noticed, first with the Nasacort, that my sense of smell was a bit "off": kept smelling a bit of "Cinnamon" (I thought) the first year. Second year--smelled like "Grasses" ...not too bad.At some point I switched to the Flonase. Now I started smelling things like garbage and rot(!) All while doing GREAT for my allergy symptoms. However, I noticed it was taking longer for "normal" smell to return after season; and finally it got where I was waiting longer & longer for ANY smell to return! (This can start affecting taste as well.)This concerned me seriously, and I won't use it any more. column1: Inflammation of the Nose due to an Allergy
column2: kat, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: First of all I've been an allergy suffer for most of my life, but now menopausal my allergies are worse.  After years or suffering with migraines, sinus infections & sinus headaches I finally gave in & saw someone.  To my shock the specialist told me had sinus polyps! These are caused by allergies, which bring on the sinus headaches, which turns into a blinding migraine.  After a painful surgery of having them removed, I was prescribed an ongoing treatment of Flonase once a day with Rhinocort. Of course the first step is a 8 oz. saline flush. Yes the polyps are back, that happened only 6 weeks after surgery.  But this with the Rhinocort are the only thing that knock down the swelling internally enough minimize the blinding migraines.  There were actually weeks at time I couldn't even work because of them.  So for all the negative effects it may have, which some I can compensated for, I don't think I could function without it. I know this because I've tried. I went off of them (Flonase & Rhinocort) for almost year. What a mistake!I paid dearly for it.  So if your side effects aren't severe, as some are, you might want to reconsider.  You might even want to see if your allergies are severe enough, if you have polyps.  The polyps make it impossible for your sinuses to drain & in my case, at times my eyes would swell shut. My surgeon never has realised me, but thank God for the wonders of science!

column1: Other
column2: Elsie, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: After my allergies caused a bad ear ache (Eustachian tube dysfunction) I went to the dr. who prescribed me Flonase. Within hours I developed a headache and just a fuziness that prevents concentration- which hasn't gone away since.  That night I began waking up at 3 am and haven't slept longer than 4.5 hours since starting taking it.  I noticed the loss of taste and appetite within a day or two, followed by loss of appetite (and really, there isn't much point in eating since there is no taste). After about 4 days I noticed anxiety and feeling on edge. Now I have been dealing with diarrhea- sever diarrhea. I'm not digesting food (it is coming out undigested which I have never seen or heard of before). So on top of not eating much, when I do I am in the bathroom within an hour. I have also been feeling feverish. I go from profound sweating to freezing.   I have lost about 3 pounds in 6 days. All of that while I have not been doing my usual workout routine of runing 25 miles a week. I do not have the energy to run and the heart racing makes it impossible. I tried for the first time today and after 10 minutes I thought I might collapse. I emailed my doctor to find out what else will help my ear ache (because it is not gone yet!).

It does not seem to affect my weight as system steroids have done to me in the past. I only use it from early March until the end of May because I am horribly allergic to tree pollen. If I didn't use it, I'd have asthma and laryngitis for three months, which was the story of my life for most of life until I was finally diagnosed in my 40s. I highly recommend this product!

column9: My turbinates located in my nose used to cause my nose to drip all the time, it was determined that I was producing in excess of two pints per day and causing me to sneeze all the time - Been taking the generic for flonase and atrovent for over two years - flonase twice in each nostril and atrovent two sprays three times per day, never any side effects with me and has been 90% better, no more runny nose, the mucus is thicker now and so I never sneeze anymore as a result - Highly recommended by me.

I quit using the Flonase six days ago and the horrible taste is starting to go away. column1: Chronic Inflammation of the Nose Not due to Allergies

column9: I was prescribed the generic equivalent of Flonase for chronic severe sinus headaches (I had them 3-5 times a week for 2 years).  This stuff took a couple of weeks to "kick in", but once it finally did my headaches mostly disappeared. I still get moderate sinus headaches on occasion, but nothing like what I had before.  I used this medication for a year with no major side effects.*  However, in the last 3 months I have begun experiencing minor nose bleeds about once a week, usually triggered by blowing my nose.  I also get a little bit of blood almost every time I blow my nose.  So far, this hasn't been bothersome enough for me to stop taking the medication. *Note: A minor side effect (not mentioned in any of the literature) that I have noticed from the beginning is that I have more boogers that I used to.  I find myself blowing my nose a lot more because of this.  Annoying, but not truly bothersome.

I started taking flonase along with claritin and my symptoms all but went away. What a relief, until the MAJOR HEADACHES started plaguing me. I stopped taking the flonase for a few days and the headaches went away immediately. I tried using it again today (after I got stuffy again) and now I have a major headache again. column1: Inflammation of the Nose due to an Allergy
column2: I'm_IL_LY, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I've always suffered with allergy rhinitis and ended up with a horribly stuffy nose. This is the first product that has ever relieved and reversed the situation. Take note that you must use the medicine as directed. When I was first prescribed this medicine my nose had literally locked up. From all the blowing of mucus and the increased inflammation I could not breath out my nose at all. My doctor prescribed this to me along with pseudoephedrine and Zyrtec and by that night I could start to breath through my nose again. At that time my prescription was to take one spray up each nostril a day. I followed the instructions that came with the spray recently because my nasal congestion was very painful again. I used 2 sprays a day. One when I woke up and one when I went to bed. Finally, my symptoms have subsided and my inflamation has went down and I can breath again. I could breath better after about 3 days. Although its a slow acting medicine at times, because it takes repeated use, it does work which many nasal sprays across the counter rarely do. I've now switched back to one spray a day and will stop using it after this week is over with. For me, I don't have to use this product everyday/all the time. I use it for my symptoms, then I use it for another week after my symptoms are gone and I'm alright. Every now and then I may use a spray up each nostril when I feel that pressure in my nose as if my allergies are going to go hay wire or when I sneeze alot. I would highly recommend this product.

column9: Gosh. Flonase really helped treat that stuffy feeling in my nose. It was great for like 3 months after which I started getting more and more headaches until my life was one long unending headache. It was really too much and I abruptly stopped it. That was a stupid thing to do, I should have told my doctor and tapered of the dose. Anyway, the headaches stopped and I switched to rhinocort aqua which screwed with my sense of smell.

column1: Inflammation of the Nose due to an Allergy
column2: sara, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I have taken Flonase with Allegra-D for 6 days.  It works great for my allergies but I stopped taking both last night because of the terrible side-effects.  I have a hard time falling asleep, vivid dreams, wake up waay too early and can't go back to sleep.  I have a thickness at the back of my throat and a tightness in my chest and throat.  I am also really really irratable and achey.  I am going to try just a saline spray and back to clariten, it doesn't work as well but the side effects aren't worth it.

column1: Inflammation of the Nose due to an Allergy
column2: Dori, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: If I take it as directed I can control my alleriges without any other medication. The problem with me is that I start to feel better and forget to use it. I have placed it on my beside to help me remember to use it each night and that has helped. It takes a few days to get the full benefit of the drug but it does work. I had horrible headaches before taking the med and that cleared up a few days after beginning. I was so stuffed up the doctor recommended using a nasal spray like Afrin for the first couple of days along with the Flonase. I used the Afrin about an hour before using the Flonase and with in two days my symptoms were gone. It works for me!Consistency is the key to this drug.

column1: Chronic Inflammation of the Nose Not due to Allergies
column2: joe, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: developed symptoms of irribility and cold sores on my lip and inside my mouth. although i have had  a cold sore rarely in the past, they were not as severe as the one i am experiencing now which i attribute to a weakened immune system caused by the flonase. the only positive is that the flonase has helped to find the problem which was an excess fluid buildup in my right ear. it seems that the tissues in my right sinus cavity are constantly swollen and contributing to this problem. i hope i can find a good ENT who can help me with this problem, since the last one said the problem was "INSIGNIFICANT" after sending me for a CAT scan and an MRI.

column1: Inflammation of the Nose due to an Allergy

column9: I have suffered from terrible seasonal allergies all my life and I have tried everything out there.  Nothing works for me as well as Flonase.  I can't live without it!  It smells a little funny but the results are amazing.  It does take a couple of days to kick in but once it does I am good to go--no more sneezing, itchy, runny nose.  Yay!
